child.geography: Oka River basin in Murom Region
child.pub-comments: Spoken by the Muromanian tribe, the language was probably part of the Mordvinic group. It became extinct around 1000 AD. Very little data exists on it.
child.publications: Multiple sources Integrated by The LINGUIST List.

child.pub-comments: This language was spoken by the Merya tribe, which lived in the modern Yaroslavl region north-east of Moscow. The language became extinct around 1000 AD, and very little is known of it.
child.publications: Multiple sources Integrated by The LINGUIST List.

child.pub-comments: The language of the Meshchera tribe on the Oka river in Russia, the language was probably Mordvinic. Very litlle is known about it.

child.pub-comments: The language of the Magyars who, under their leader Árpád, invaded and settled Hungary, c.895. It was also the language of the early Hungarian state which they founded. Until the 11th century AD it was written in a runic script (called the Rovás) which is related to that of the oldest Turkic writing. Most Old Hungarian texts in this script were destroyed when King István (Stephen) converted to Christianity in the early 11th century A.D., and the Roman alphabet was introduced. The earliest extant Hungarian documents in the Roman alphabet go back to the 13th cent. and are the oldest texts of a Uralic language. Late 9th century – 15th century. Once spoken in Croatia, Romania, Serbia, Hungary.
